First Avenue, at East 37th Street, showing the Queens Midtown Tunnel under construction at the S. W. corner. The buildings on the right are on the east side of the Avenue, extending from 37th to 39th Street's. The stacks shown are atop the Consolidated Edison Co. generating plant at the East River. The photographer is viewing northeastward from a vantage point on 36th Street, between First and Second Avenue's.

June 28, 1939
October 11, 1939

P. L. Sperr

First Avenue, at East 37th Street, showing the Queens Midtown Tunnel under construction at the S. W. corner. The buildings on the right are on the east side of the Avenue, extending from 37th to 39th Street's. The stacks shown are atop the Consolidated Edison Co. generating plant at the East River. The photographer is viewing northeastward from a vantage point on 36th Street, between First and Second Avenue's.

June 28, 1939
October 11, 1939

P. L. Sperr

First Avenue, west side, from E. 37th to 38th Streets, showing a fenced in clearance thru which is running the diagonal cut for the Queens Midtown tunnel. At the right is the Eletco Co. warehouse, housing the "United Parcel" service.

January, 7, 1939

Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

First Avenue, east side, north from E. 37th to 39th Streets. The former Kips Bay Brewery occupies the 37th-38th Street frontage, while above same are power houses of the Consolidated Edison Co.

Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

January 7, 1939

E. 37th Street, west of First Avenue. Across the foreground and enclosed by fences is the diagonal cut that will carry the approach to the Queens Midtown Tunnel.

January 7, 1939

Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

E. 37th Street, west from First Avenue, showing in the foreground the Queens Midtown Tunnel clearance. The balance of the buildings on the left were subsequently demolished. This included St. Gabriel's Church appearing in the right center. Note the hazy outline of the Empire State Building in the background.

January 7, 1939

Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

East 37th Street, at First Avenue, showing constructional details of the Manhattan Approach to the Queens Midtown Tunnel under the East River. The buildings on the left are on the north side of 37th Street; those on the right are on the east side of First Avenue. The photographers vantage point is 36th Street, east of Second Avenue. The direction is northeast.
October 11, 1939
April 11, 1940
P. L. Sperr

East 37th Street, at First Avenue, showing constructional details of the Manhattan Approach to the Queens Midtown Tunnel under the East River. The buildings on the left are on the north side of 37th Street; those on the right are on the east side of First Avenue. The photographers vantage point is 36th Street, east of Second Avenue. The direction is northeast.
October 11, 1939
April 11, 1940
P. L. Sperr

East 37th Street, west from First Avenue, showing progress on the demolition for the Midtown-Queens Tunnel.

In a skeletal condition stands St. Gabriel's Church and School. Tenements on the north side of this thoroughfare will remain. Note the Second Avenue Elevated and the towering Empire State Building.

P. L. Sperr

May 27, 1939
Views: 1-2-3

East 37th Street, west from First Avenue, showing progress on the demolition for the Midtown-Queens Tunnel.

In a skeletal condition stands St. Gabriel's Church and School. Tenements on the north side of this thoroughfare will remain. Note the Second Avenue Elevated and the towering Empire State Building.

P. L. Sperr

May 27, 1939
Views: 1-2-3

East 37th Street, west from First Avenue, showing progress on the demolition for the Midtown-Queens Tunnel.

In a skeletal condition stands St. Gabriel's Church and School. Tenements on the north side of this thoroughfare will remain. Note the Second Avenue Elevated and the towering Empire State Building.

P. L. Sperr

May 27, 1939
Views: 1-2-3

300 to 310 E. 37th Street, at, adjoining and east of the S. E. corner of Second Avenue (right), as viewed south westward from a point midway between First and Second Avenues.

Prominently shown is St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church established here August 15, 1859 by the Rev. William H. Clowry. The late Cardinal Farley, then a Monsignor, was pastor from 1884 to 1902. His assistant during part of that time was the subsequent Cardinal, Patrick J. Hayes. For an account of the last Mass held here, see the New York Times of January 16, 1939. Demolition will occur in June 1939.

January 25, 1939

Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

First Avenue, at East 37th Street, showing the entrance to the Midtown-Queens Tunnel at the S. E. corner. The industrial plants shown are on the east side of the Avenue. East 37th Street proper is on the left. The Tunnel curves northward under the Avenue to pass under the East River at about 40th Street.

September 21, 1940
No's. 1-2

P. L. Sperr
